_data.title: Dashboard

children.value:
Regardless of the solution used to collect a payment all payment information and any additional information collected
through your portals are searchable and downloadable from your client dashboard.
You can log into your dashboard
By default you will be able to download this information in

format. However, should you require a
custom file format please contact your account manager who will be able to assist you with configuring this.

In addition to downloading payment information directly from the dashboard it is also possible for us to automatically
ditribute these files to an email address and/or an SFTP location when a disbursement is made to your nominated bank account.
This file will contain details of all the payments that make up that disbursement. Again, should you wish to configure
these setting please contact your account manager.

_data.text:
Regardless of the solution used to collect a payment all payment information and any additional information collected 
through your portals are searchable and downloadable from your client dashboard.

You can log into your dashboard [here](https://app.flywire.com/).

## File Downloads

By default you will be able to download this information in `.csv` format. However, should you require a 
custom file format please contact your account manager who will be able to assist you with configuring this.

## SFTP and Email Distribution

In addition to downloading payment information directly from the dashboard it is also possible for us to automatically 
ditribute these files to an email address and/or an SFTP location when a disbursement is made to your nominated bank account. 
This file will contain details of all the payments that make up that disbursement. Again, should you wish to configure 
these setting please contact your account manager.

_data.title: Introduction

children.value:
Flywire offers a variety of ways to integrate our payment solutions into your workflow. Please use this guide to understand the
available options and assess which method will be most appropriate for you. If you have any queries or would like guidance please
reach out to your account manager or contact a member of the soltions team for support at

At Flywire we collect payments into payment portals which are identified by a unique three letter code - you may be allocated
multiple portals depending on your requirements. Each of these portals can be configured to collect different information from
the payer when making a payment.

_data.text:
Flywire offers a variety of ways to integrate our payment solutions into your workflow. Please use this guide to understand the 
available options and assess which method will be most appropriate for you. If you have any queries or would like guidance please 
reach out to your account manager or contact a member of the soltions team for support at solutions@flywire.com.

## Fundamentals

At Flywire we collect payments into payment portals which are identified by a unique three letter code - you may be allocated 
multiple portals depending on your requirements. Each of these portals can be configured to collect different information from 
the payer when making a payment.

_data.title: Your Portal Configuration

To view your portal configuration please enter your portal code below.

<portal-config></portal-config>

_data.title: Repeat Payments

children.value: Flywireâ€™s repeat payment functionality is accessed via the

. The following guidance assumes
that you are familiar with the available options for the checkout and will focus only on repeat payment options.
There are several different types of repeat payment model each providing different degrees of automation and customisation to suit your needs.

Using scheduled payments is the simplest way to instruct Flywire to collect future payments on specific dates for specific amounts.
Using this model you redirect your customer to store their card details using the checkout and supply a future schedule of payments.
You can then manage this schedule (e.g. edit amounts and dates, request card updates etc.) via your dashboard and the Flywire platform
will process the payments and send communications on your behalf at the appropriate times.
The following code sample shows how to configure the checkout to initiate a schedule of payments.
// Specifiy the returnUrl or an onCompleteCallback handler
// Other checkout parameters (e.g. pass some payer info and set requestPayerInfo to true)
// The amount must be 0 for scheduled payments
parameter is used to show you a description of the purpose of the payment in your dashboard.
parameter must be passed in as future UTC dates. Payments are processed at 08:00 (8am) UTC every day.

It is possible to schedule the capture of an immediate payment by specifiying todayâ€™s date (in the UTC timezone) which the platform will process
immediately after storing the card details. To check the outcome of this payment you will need to log into your dashboard.
Once a the payer has successfully entered their details and the checkout modal is closed, control is passed back to to the host page using either the
The following parameters are included either as parameters in the the query string or as the JSON args passed to the handler.
- a unique identifier for this schedule
An example of the args passed to the handler is:

Ongoing management of the schedule can only be undertaken from the Flywire dashboard. Please contact your account manager for
access and/or training on how to do this.

Tokenization provides you with the greatest degree of control and flexibility over future payment processing. In this model
Flywire will simply ask your customer to enter their card details, securely save them in our PCI compliant vault and then give
you a token back which you can then use to make future charges against their card by calling the charge endpoint.
// The amount must be 0 for tokenization
// Specifiy the returnUrl or an onCompleteCallback handler
// Other checkout parameters (e.g. pass payer info or set requestPayerInfo to true)

as shown above. Payer details
can be passed in as paramters or the the

to prompt the payer to enter this information into the
checkout window. There is no need to pass any

information and any
information you do pass will be ignored. Callbacks can be configured to allow you to receive payment status updates.

Once a the payer has successfully entered their details and the checkout modal is closed control is passed back to you either using
the
The following parameters are included either as parameters in the the query string or as the JSON args passed to the handler.
- can be used to identify the card
Store this to make future charges against the tokenized card
To charge a card you need to submit a
request to the charge endpoint. The url of this endpoint varies by environment.
The content-type of the message should be application/json and the body should contain the the following parameters as a minimum.
"These fields will vary according to your portal configuration"

Although the call is synchronous and the status is returned in the response it is also possible to hook into the
standard
for payments by supplying both a callback id and url as follows.
Please note that tokenized payment callbacks are currently only sent using version 1 of the notifcations.
"These fields will vary according to your portal configuration"

Finally, if you captured the original card holder details and know these have been updated since the initial card tokenization,
these values should be supplied for
"These fields will vary according to your portal configuration"

You should use the HTTP response code to determine if a charge was successful. In most scenarios additional details is
contained in the response body and is formatted as
The call to charge the card has been successful. The payment reference is contained in the body.
If you supplied a callback url and id to subscribe to notifications then these will fire too.
Bad request. The message body is malformed. A non-exhaustive list of the more common issues follows.
Please contact your account manager if you receive this error.
The response body in this instance is not formatted as JSON
The response body in this instance is not formatted as JSON
Incorrect recipient code used for the supplied token
Recipient not found. This error is returned if the recipient code used doesnâ€™t match any record.
Validation errors. Each error in the arry will contain details of the specific validation rule that has been violated. The format is as follows:
Unknown error encountered while charging the payor.
The response body in this instance is not formatted as JSON

_data.text:
## Overview

Dynamic payment links allow you to simply direct customers over to your Flywire-hosted payment portal page and supply 
key data to pre-populate the payment pages in the URL.

```
https://app.flywire.com/solutions/quick-pay/?code=FWB&env=demo&amount=2000&firstName=John
```

#### Common Uses

There are a number of reasons to use dynamic payment links with Flywire. Here are a few of the most popular reasons:

<list :items="items" type='success'></list>

## Link Creation

Creating a link is as simple as constructing a URL as detailed in the steps below.

### Base URL

Use the base URL below as the starting point for generating the payment link. 

```
https://app.flywire.com/solutions/quick-pay/
```

### Query String

All the other parameters are then added as query string key value pairs.

<alert type="warning">

All query string parameter values should be **URL encoded**. 

To make reading the guide below easier the example values have not been encoded. Omitting this step in your sysmtes may generate broken links.

</alert>

### Environment

Add an `env` parameter to point to the desired environment you would like to create a payment in. Whenever testing, you can use 
Flywire's `demo` environment:

| Parameter | Description              | Type       | Example          |
| --------- | ------------------------ | ---------- | ---------------- |
| `env`     | The desired environment  | `OPTIONAL` | `env=demo`       |

- `demo`
- `prod` (Default)

<alert>

By default the **production environment** will be used if no `env` parameter is supplied within the URL.

</alert>

### Code

The next step is to start building the URL query string by adding your three letter portal code in as the `code` parameter.

| Parameter | Description                                    | Type       | Example    |
| --------- | ---------------------------------------------- | ---------- | ---------- |
| `code`    | Flywire recipient code for processing payments | `REQUIRED` | `code=FWB` |

### Amount

Add the `amount` parameter to designate the intended value for the payment. The currency is determined by the collection currency of the portal.

| Parameter | Description                                | Type       | Example                |
| --------- | ------------------------------------------ | ---------- | ---------------------- |
| `amount`  | Payment amount. Must be greater than zero. | `REQUIRED` | `amount=1234.56`       |

### Payer Data

You should now pass through any information you would like to pre-populate into the checkout's payments pages. It is possible to pass through 
values for any of the payment items or fields shown in your portal configuration as query string parameters.

| Parameter   | Description          | Type       | Example                  |
| ----------- | -------------------- | ---------- | ------------------------ |
| `firstName` | First Name           | `OPTIONAL` | `firstName=John`         |
| `lastName`  | Last Name            | `OPTIONAL` | `lastName=Doe`           |
| `address`   | Address              | `OPTIONAL` | `address=21 Jump St`     |
| `city`      | City                 | `OPTIONAL` | `city=Boston`            |
| `country`   | Country (ISO-2 Code) | `OPTIONAL` | `country=US`             |
| `email`     | Email                | `OPTIONAL` | `email=jdoe@flywire.com` |
| `phone`     | Phone Number         | `OPTIONAL` | `phone=+16173214567`     |

### Custom Data

Your portal can be setup with custom fields to collect any additional information that would be helpful for reconciliation / reporting. Check
your portal configuration and add parameters using their field name as necessary.

| Parameter           | Description               | Type       | Example                      |
| ------------------- | ------------------------- | ---------- | ---------------------------- |
| `booking_reference` | Unique booking identifier | `OPTIONAL` | `booking_reference=REF-1234` |
| `invoice_number`    | Unique invoice identifier | `OPTIONAL` | `invoice_number=INV-1234`    |

### Display Options

You can add a title and sub-title to the payment page to add some additional context to your payer as to what the payment is for, or just
for a welcome message

| Parameter     | Description         | Type       | Example                                        |
| --------------| --------------------| ---------- | ---------------------------------------------- |
| `title`       | The main title      | `OPTIONAL` | `title=Please make your payment.`              |
| `subTitle`    | A smaller sub-title | `OPTIONAL` | `subTitle=We look forward to seeing you soon!` |

### Filtering

If you would like to filter the payment options available for a specific link you can use the `filterType` and `filterCcy` parameters.

These should be provided as a comma separated list of availale values as described in the checkout documentation [here](/en/checkout/implementation/#filtering).

| Parameter    | Description              | Type       | Example                         |
| -------------| -------------------------| ---------- | ------------------------------- |
| `filterType` | Payment type filters     | `OPTIONAL` | `filterType=online,credit_card` |
| `filterCcy`  | Payment currency filters | `OPTIONAL` | `filterCcy=fx`                  |

### Webhook Notifications

If you would like to recieve webhook notifiations for any payments that are processed please include **both** the `callbackUrl` and 
`callbackId` paramenters.

Please refer to the [webhook notifications](/en/webhooks/notifications-v1/) documentation for details on how to process notifications.
Currently only version 1 of the callbacks is supported.

| Parameter     | Description                            | Type       | Example                                                         |
| --------------| -------------------------------------- | ---------- | --------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `callbackUrl` | The webhook URL                        | `OPTIONAL` | `callbackUrl=https://api.your-domain.com/flywire-notifications` |
| `callbackId`  | The unique identifier for this payment | `OPTIONAL` | `callbackId=REF1234`                                                       |

<alert>

We recommend you also obfuscate the URL using the anti-tampering options below if using webhook notifications. 

</alert>

### Anti-Tampering

To deter payers from tampering with the values in the query string it can base64 then URL encoded.

<code-group>
  <code-block label="Javascript" active>

```js
const baseUrl = 'https://app.flywire.com/solutions/quick-pay/';

// Note: does not include the leading query string ?
let queryString = 'code=FWB';
queryString += '&amount=1234.56'
queryString += '&callbackUrl=' + encodeURIComponent('https://api.your-domain.com/flywire-notifications');
queryString += '&callbackId=' + encodeURIComponent('REF1234');

queryString = btoa(queryString);
queryString = encodeURIComponent(queryString);

const finalUrl = baseUrl + '?' + queryString;
```

  </code-block>
</code-group>

<alert type="warning">

These anti-tampering methods **do not prevent determined customers from decoding and editing the URL**. However, it does prevent casual
customers from viewing and changing the details in the URL.

</alert>

_data.title: v1. Notifications

children.value: We strongly recommend that you use

with a callback ID and URL to
be able to receive payment status notifications you will need to implement a web-hook to listen for these updates. This should be
a publicly available URL.
The callbacks will be triggered by the payment being set to one of four statuses:
â€‹. These updates cannot be repressed and are sent for all payment methods.
Notification for all new payment requests
stage, no funds have been received by Flywire. This update occurs in near-real-time.

payments cannot be cancelled by the payer.

For each change to a paymentâ€™s status the Flywire payments platform will send a POST request to the specified â€‹callback URL containing the following JSON payload:
Flywireâ€™s unique ID for the payment
The time of the status change
Your unique reference for the payment as set when configuring the portal
When Flywire tries to send a notification to a callback URL and we receive an error, we automatically re-attempt three times and log all failures:
After a delay of 180 seconds (3 minutes)
After a delay of 1800 seconds (30 minutes)
After a delay of 10800 seconds (3 hours)
When using the callback feature please refer to our
to ensure that you have all use cases covered.
In order to verify the integrity and authenticity of messages sent to your web-hook these POST requests can include a X-Flywire-Digest header.
header is the base 64 encoded HMAC SHA256 hash of the message body and a shared secret. Please contact your account manager to arrange the transfer of your shared secret.

We ask all clients using the callback features to verify the following payment progression and regression cases during testing to ensure their systems are capable of handling our callbacks appropriately. To understand these case scenarios there is an assumed knowledge of the general Flywire funds flow. For more context, please speak with your account manager.

It is important to understand the context of each case and its potential impact on how you intend to use Flywire. Depending on your implementation some scenarios may not directly impact your processes.
(using bank transfer as the payment method)
(using card or an online payment method)
The success of these three tests allow us to confirm that the core payment flows operate as expected in the overall user process.
(using bank transfer as the payment method)
This test ensures that your platform does not recognise
Payment Scenario: A bank transfer payment is cancelled automatically when Flywire does not receive the funds. Although this booking now has a status of

, it is possible that the payer sent funds that did not arrive before the automatic cancellation, or funds were delayed because of their bank. If Flywire receives the funds after the automatic cancellation, providing that the FX rate position is similar, Flywire will still process the payment against the same payment ID, moving the status from
and back through the standard path.
In both cases above, the payment is placed on hold, this is an internal status which translates to an
status being communicated in the callback. The reasons why a payment could be placed on hold are:
A payment made via card or an online method has been

, however, prior to Flywire disbursing funds to the client, the payer contacts Flywire as theyâ€™ve made a mistake and would like a refund. Flywire would place this payment on hold and contact you to confirm whether we should deliver the funds despite the refund request or return the funds to the payer.
We would not return these funds without your approval

A payment is made via any method and Flywire receive the funds. The transaction is flagged as suspicious and is placed on hold. The payment is manually checked to determine legitimacy. If the alert is deemed to be a false positive, Flywire will deliver the funds. If the payment is deemed to be suspicious and/or the alert cannot be deemed a false-positive, Flywire will notify the client and return the funds to the payer
This can only occur when using bank transfer as the payment method as the payments are completed outside of the Flywire platform.
: A payer books an exchange rate with Flywire to send $2000 via bank transfer. An

status and value of $2000 is sent via the callback notification. When the payer sends funds via online banking or at their physical bank, they send above or below the quoted amount of $2000. Flywire will accept this amount if it is within an accepted threshold. A
status with an updated value in the amount parameter is sent to the client via the notification.
200.00 USD or equivalent under the booked exchange amount
1000.00 USD or equivalent over the booked exchange amount
Outside of these tolerances, if a payment is excessively under or over the
value, we will contact you to ask if you would like to accept the payment or return it back to the payer. At this stage, the booking would be placed on hold and follow the
amount will always be the same as the

_data.text: We strongly recommend that you use version 2 of the webhook notifications. If you configured the [Flywire checkout](/en/checkout/implementation/#configure-server-callbacks) with a callback ID and URL to be able to receive payment status notifications you will need to implement a web-hook to listen for these updates. This should be a publicly available URL. ## Payment Statuses The callbacks will be triggered by the payment being set to one of four statuses: `â€‹initiated`, `guaranteed`, `delivered` or `cancelled`â€‹. These updates cannot be repressed and are sent for all payment methods. | Status | Description | | ------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `initiated` | Notification for all new payment requests `initiated` through Flywire. At the `initiated` stage, no funds have been received by Flywire. This update occurs in near-real-time. | | `guaranteed` | The status changes from `initiated` to `guaranteed` when funds are received by Flywire. At this point, you are guaranteed the funds. This update occurs in near-real-time. | | `delivered` | The status changes from `guaranteed` to `delivered` when funds have been sent to you in your daily batch disbursement. Transactions will update to delivered at a set time each day. | | `cancelled` | The status changes from `initiated` to `cancelled` when the payment has been cancelled by either the payer or by Flywire (after 8 days have passed from payment initiation and no funds have been received). Note that `guaranteed` and `delivered` payments cannot be cancelled by the payer. | The `delivered` status is the **only** terminal status - it is not possible for the status of a payment marked as `delivered` to change. ## Message Structure For each change to a paymentâ€™s status the Flywire payments platform will send a POST request to the specified â€‹callback URL containing the following JSON payload: ```json { "id": "FWB123456789", "amount": "100.00", "status": "initiated", "at": "2021-10-17 08:15:30 UTC", "callback_id": "INV12345-RAND4321" } ``` ```json { "id": "FWB123456789", "amount": "100.00", "status": "guaranteed", "at": "2021-10-17 08:15:30 UTC", "callback_id": "INV12345-RAND4321" } ``` ```json { "id": "FWB123456789", "amount": "100.00", "status": "delivered", "at": "2021-10-17 08:15:30 UTC", "callback_id": "INV12345-RAND4321" } ``` ```json { "id": "FWB123456789", "amount": "100.00", "status": "guaranteed", "at": "2021-10-17 08:15:30 UTC", "callback_id": "INV12345-RAND4321" } ``` | Property | Description | | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `id` | Flywireâ€™s unique ID for the payment | | `amount` | Payment amount | | `status` | The status of the payment [`initiated`, `guaranteed`, `delivered`, `cancelled`] | | `at` | The time of the status change | | `callback_id` | Your unique reference for the payment as set when configuring the portal | When Flywire tries to send a notification to a callback URL and we receive an error, we automatically re-attempt three times and log all failures: 1. After a delay of 180 seconds (3 minutes) 2. After a delay of 1800 seconds (30 minutes) 3. After a delay of 10800 seconds (3 hours) When using the callback feature please refer to our [payment scenarios](/en/webhooks/notifications-v1/#payment-flows) to ensure that you have all use cases covered. ## Authentication In order to verify the integrity and authenticity of messages sent to your web-hook these POST requests can include a X-Flywire-Digest header. The `X-Flywire-Digest` header is the base 64 encoded HMAC SHA256 hash of the message body and a shared secret. Please contact your account manager to arrange the transfer of your shared secret. ```js const crypto = require("crypto"); app.post("/flywire-notification", (req, res) => { const notification = req.body; const sharedSecret = "YOUR SHARED SECRET"; const requestDigest = req.header("X-Flywire-Digest"); const serverDigest = digest(notification, sharedSecret); if (requestDigest === serverDigest) { // Process notification } res.sendStatus(200); }); function digest(data, sharedSecret) { const hmac = crypto.createHmac("sha256", sharedSecret); hmac.update(JSON.stringify(data)); return hmac.digest("base64"); } ``` ```php $value) { if ($name == $header) { return $value; } } } ?> ``` ## Payment Flows We ask all clients using the callback features to verify the following payment progression and regression cases during testing to ensure their systems are capable of handling our callbacks appropriately. To understand these case scenarios there is an assumed knowledge of the general Flywire funds flow. For more context, please speak with your account manager. It is important to understand the context of each case and its potential impact on how you intend to use Flywire. Depending on your implementation some scenarios may not directly impact your processes. ### Standard Payment 1. `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `delivered` (using bank transfer as the payment method) 2. `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `delivered` (using card or an online payment method) 3. `initiated` > `cancelled` (using any payment method) The success of these three tests allow us to confirm that the core payment flows operate as expected in the overall user process. ### Re-initiated Cancelled Payment 1. `initiated` > `cancelled` > `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `delivered` (using bank transfer as the payment method) This test ensures that your platform does not recognise `cancelled` as an absolute end-point. Payment Scenario: A bank transfer payment is cancelled automatically when Flywire does not receive the funds. Although this booking now has a status of `cancelled`, it is possible that the payer sent funds that did not arrive before the automatic cancellation, or funds were delayed because of their bank. If Flywire receives the funds after the automatic cancellation, providing that the FX rate position is similar, Flywire will still process the payment against the same payment ID, moving the status from `cancelled` to `initiated` and back through the standard path. ### Held Payment 1. `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `initiated` (due to a hold release) > `delivered` 2. `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `cancelled` In both cases above, the payment is placed on hold, this is an internal status which translates to an `initiated` status being communicated in the callback. The reasons why a payment could be placed on hold are: **Payment Scenario A:â€‹** A payment made via card or an online method has been `guaranteed`, however, prior to Flywire disbursing funds to the client, the payer contacts Flywire as theyâ€™ve made a mistake and would like a refund. Flywire would place this payment on hold and contact you to confirm whether we should deliver the funds despite the refund request or return the funds to the payer. We would not return these funds without your approval **Payment Scenario B:â€‹** A payment is made via any method and Flywire receive the funds. The transaction is flagged as suspicious and is placed on hold. The payment is manually checked to determine legitimacy. If the alert is deemed to be a false positive, Flywire will deliver the funds. If the payment is deemed to be suspicious and/or the alert cannot be deemed a false-positive, Flywire will notify the client and return the funds to the payer ### Guaranteed with Different Amount `initiated` (\$2000) > `guaranteed` (amount changed) > `delivered` This can only occur when using bank transfer as the payment method as the payments are completed outside of the Flywire platform. **Payment Scenario**: A payer books an exchange rate with Flywire to send \$2000 via bank transfer. An `initiated` status and value of $2000 is sent via the callback notification. When the payer sends funds via online banking or at their physical bank, they send above or below the quoted amount of $2000. Flywire will accept this amount if it is within an accepted threshold. A `guaranteed` status with an updated value in the amount parameter is sent to the client via the notification. Flywire amount change tolerances are: - 200.00 USD or equivalent under the booked exchange amount - 1000.00 USD or equivalent over the booked exchange amount Outside of these tolerances, if a payment is excessively under or over the `initiated` value, we will contact you to ask if you would like to accept the payment or return it back to the payer. At this stage, the booking would be placed on hold and follow the [payments on hold flow](#held-payment). The `guaranteed` amount will always be the same as the `delivered` amount.

_data.title: Implementation

children.value:
If you want to maintain complete control of the customer data capture within your site then the Flywire checkout
offers the most streamlined payment experience available. Customers remain on your site and the checkout modal
pop-up allows the payer to chose their payment method and complete the payment in as little as one step.

On completion of a payment the customer is returned back to your site to a specified redirection URL or through a
callback function. In addition, real-time notifications can be enabled to allow you update your back-office systems
with payment status information.

There are several configuration options available when using the Flywire checkout. Please take a look at
the following sample page and configuration options to decide which is most appropriate for your use case.
All the available configuration options are explained
This is a simplified sample page demonstrating how to initiate a payment through Flywire.
Add the flywire-payment script to your page
Add a button (or other element or event) to trigger the Flywire checkout

// Add an event handler
      function pay() {
Set your portal specific payment configuration options. Please refer to the samples
Finally, initiate the payment with the specified configuration and render the checkout.

In order to avoid payers clicking through unnecessary steps in the checkout you can set the

This is useful if you are unsure whether either the payer details or custom field values you supply will be complete or
partial.

if all the required information has been supplied the checkout process will jump
to the next step automatically.

There is also the option to skip only a certain step. You can do this by specifying the step name. For example
you can skip the custom fields step if it has been completed by specifying

if you want to give the payer the chance to edit the fields information.
By default Flywire will show all available payment options for a given a portal during checkout.

In certain circumstances it may be desirable to restrict the methods available to your customers based on a set of rules (e.g. only accept bank
transfers for payments overs a certain value, only show card payments a certain time before a booking etc).

To enable this the Flywire checkout allows you to filter the payment options offered by payment type and by payer currency.
Filters are supplied in the
(Show all card payment options e.g. debit cards)
(Show all online alternative payment options e.g. PayPal)
(Only show payment options in the payers local currency e.g. only GBP options for a payer in the UK)
(Only show payment options not in the payers local currency e.g. everything but GBP options for a payer in the UK)
(Only show payment options that are a different currency to the collection currency)
(Only show payment options that are in the same currency as the collection currency)
// Only allow local card and online payments

Flywire makes every effort to display the payment option to payers in the most appropriate order based on payer
behaviour.
However, we recognise that you may prefer to change this order to better suit yours and your payers needs.

To enable this the Flywire checkout allows you to sort the payment options offered by payment type, payment currency and/or amount.
The sort orders are supplied in the
(This refers to online alternative payment options e.g. PayPal)
// Show the cheapest local payment option first but prefer bank transfers
// over cards and online methods if they are the same price
are set in the sort array affects the final sort order.
parameter in query string of the return URL and in the args supplied to the
To include your own parameter in the generation of the signature please supply a value to the

We recommend that you set this to a value that uniquely identifies the entity in your platform that this payment relates
to - e.g. a booking reference, reservation number, registration id etc.

Should you need to keep a reference to the checkout window in order to close it programatically you can get the handle to
the checkout modal from the
The window handle has two functions availale on it
Flywire performs quality checks on the information provided for every payment.

In cases where the information provided doesnâ€™t pass our validation checks it will be processed but then placed in a quality
check queue. To reduce the chances of payments being held in this queue the Flywire checkout validates the information provided
up-front and alert payers to any potential validation errors before processing.
Should you wish to disable this feature you can set the
// Skip the quality check validation rules

If you would like Flywire to automatically distribute part of the payment amount to one or more of your partners
(that must also be enrolled with Flywire) you can use the
parameter to set up split payments.
Each payable takes the amount specified in the payable away from the

of the payment and pays it out to the specified recipient.
The following parameters make up a split payment configuration within the
(mandatory) - must not exceed the base amount
// The base portal code - any remaining amount left after the payables
// distribution will be sent to this account (in this instance 70.00)
// The base (total) amount charged to the payer
Please bear in mind the following constraints when using split payments.
array must contain at least one element.
must be a valid Flywire 3 letter code and cannot be be the same as the base payment
parameters must not exceed the base payment amount.

The language of the payment experience can be fixed by supplying the locale parameter. If this value is
omittred (recommended) then the browser language will be used (where supported)
// Set the locale the checkout should be displayed in

payment relates to - e.g. a booking reference, reservation number, registration id etc.

For backwards compatibility we default to use version 1 of the callbacks however, we recommend that you use the latest
version (currently version 2) as these notifications contain additional information and status transitions.
Please refer to the webhooks documentation for details on how to process notifications.

and the args supplied to the

never send your shared secret to the clientâ€™s browser

What follows is some suggested guidance on how to successfully implement the Flywire checkout. However, you should read the documentation fully
and determine what is appropriate for your use case. If you need to discuss with Flywire please contact your account manager to arrange a call.
This assumes you will be using version
Configure the checkout with the appropriate parameters ensuring you include values for the

and parameters.
It often makes sense to use the same value for both the
When a payer selects a payment option and continues to the payment page an

. This includes the payment method (bank_transfer, credit_card, online etc) and additional metadata (varies between methods).
For bank transfers it may make sense for you to hold a booking or reserve product as the customer still needs to send Flywire the money to our bank account.
We give customers a certain amount of time to do this as indicated by the expiry date in the notification message.
When the payer completes the payment then
query string or in the args supplied to the
Perform this verification on your server.

Use this information
to show the user the appropriate messaging - do not use it to release products or sevices to your customers.
Use the status and payment method information returned in the webhook notifications sent to your

to progress any orders, release
services, complete bookings etc. This can either be done on

(Flywire has remitted the funds)
to your registered bank account. A
notification will be sent to you when the booking expires.

_data.title: v2. Notifications

children.value:
with a callback ID and URL and
version

to be able to receive payment status notifications you will need to implement a web-hook to listen for these
updates. This should be a publicly available URL.
The callbacks will be triggered by the payment being set to one of six statuses:
â€‹. These updates cannot be repressed and are sent for all payment methods.
Notification for all new payment requests
stage, no funds have been received by Flywire. This update occurs in near-real-time.
when Flywire has the confirmation of funds being received or captured.

when funds are received by Flywire and all the necessary validations for that payment method and corridor are successful. At this point, the client is guaranteed the funds. This update occurs in near-real-time.
when funds have been sent to you in your daily batch disbursement. Transactions will update to delivered at a set time each day.

The status applies for online payments like credit cards. If the payer tries to pay with a card and thereâ€™s an issue to collect the funds, a failed status update will be triggered. This update will contain information about the card used and the reason why it failed. Any new attempt will trigger a new failed attempt or the status will channge to
when the payment has either been cancelled by either the payer or expired. Note that
payments cannot be cancelled by the payer.
terminal status - it is not possible for the status of a payment marked as
For each change to a paymentâ€™s status the Flywire payments platform will send a POST request to the specified â€‹callback URL containing the following JSON payload:
"Your transaction has not been successful, please try again. If the error persists select a different payment method or contact our customer support team."
The time of the status change
that contains additional info about the payment
Flywireâ€™s unique ID for the payment
Payment amount in payer's originating currency specified in subunits (ie. â‚¬15.49 would be 1549)
Payment amount in recipient's settlement currency in subunits (ie. $10.99 would be 1099)
The date in which the booking will expire
Your unique reference that was set during the original payment initialization (if using the
The country the payer is paying from
containing details around the payment's method
Object containing any custom field data (check
Human friendly description behind why the payment had failed
Error code that provides more details about the failure
Last four digits of the card

The fields marked by the asterisk are only returned for specific card payments. Please check with your account manager to see if you should expect to receive these fields in your payment method object.
When Flywire tries to send a notification to a callback URL and we receive an error, we automatically re-attempt three times and log all failures:
After a delay of 180 seconds (3 minutes)
After a delay of 1800 seconds (30 minutes)
After a delay of 10800 seconds (3 hours)
When using the callback feature please refer to our
to ensure that you have all use cases covered.
In order to verify the integrity and authenticity of messages sent to your web-hook these POST requests can include a X-Flywire-Digest header.
header is the base 64 encoded HMAC SHA256 hash of the message body and a shared secret. Please contact your account manager to arrange the transfer of your shared secret.

We ask all clients using the callback features to verify the following payment progression and regression cases during testing to ensure their systems are capable of handling our callbacks appropriately. To understand these case scenarios there is an assumed knowledge of the general Flywire funds flow. For more context, please speak with your account manager.

It is important to understand the context of each case and its potential impact on how you intend to use Flywire. Depending on your implementation some scenarios may not directly impact your processes.
(using bank transfer as the payment method)
(using card or an online payment method)
The success of these three tests allow us to confirm that the core payment flows operate as expected in the overall user process.
(using bank transfer as the payment method)
This test ensures that your platform does not recognise
Payment Scenario: A bank transfer payment is cancelled automatically when Flywire does not receive the funds. Although this booking now has a status of

, it is possible that the payer sent funds that did not arrive before the automatic cancellation, or funds were delayed because of their bank. If Flywire receives the funds after the automatic cancellation, providing that the FX rate position is similar, Flywire will still process the payment against the same payment ID, moving the status from
and back through the standard path.
In both cases above, the payment is placed on hold, this is an internal status which translates to an
status being communicated in the callback. The reasons why a payment could be placed on hold are:
A payment made via card or an online method has been

, however, prior to Flywire disbursing funds to the client, the payer contacts Flywire as theyâ€™ve made a mistake and would like a refund. Flywire would place this payment on hold and contact you to confirm whether we should deliver the funds despite the refund request or return the funds to the payer.
We would not return these funds without your approval

A payment is made via any method and Flywire receive the funds. The transaction is flagged as suspicious and is placed on hold. The payment is manually checked to determine legitimacy. If the alert is deemed to be a false positive, Flywire will deliver the funds. If the payment is deemed to be suspicious and/or the alert cannot be deemed a false-positive, Flywire will notify the client and return the funds to the payer
This can only occur when using bank transfer as the payment method as the payments are completed outside of the Flywire platform.
: A payer books an exchange rate with Flywire to send $2000 via bank transfer. An

status and value of $2000 is sent via the callback notification. When the payer sends funds via online banking or at their physical bank, they send above or below the quoted amount of $2000. Flywire will accept this amount if it is within an accepted threshold. A
status with an updated value in the amount parameter is sent to the client via the notification.
200.00 USD or equivalent under the booked exchange amount
1000.00 USD or equivalent over the booked exchange amount
Outside of these tolerances, if a payment is excessively under or over the
value, we will contact you to ask if you would like to accept the payment or return it back to the payer. At this stage, the booking would be placed on hold and follow the
amount will always be the same as the

_data.text: If you configured the [Flywire checkout](/en/checkout/implementation/#configure-server-callbacks) with a callback ID and URL and version `"2"` to be able to receive payment status notifications you will need to implement a web-hook to listen for these updates. This should be a publicly available URL. ## Payment Statuses The callbacks will be triggered by the payment being set to one of six statuses: `â€‹initiated`, `processed`, `guaranteed`, `delivered`, `failed` or `cancelled`â€‹. These updates cannot be repressed and are sent for all payment methods. | Status | Description | | ------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `initiated` | Notification for all new payment requests `initiated` through Flywire. At the `initiated` stage, no funds have been received by Flywire. This update occurs in near-real-time. | | `processed` | The status changes from `initiated` to `processed` when Flywire has the confirmation of funds being received or captured. | | `guaranteed` | The status changes from `processed` to `guaranteed` when funds are received by Flywire and all the necessary validations for that payment method and corridor are successful. At this point, the client is guaranteed the funds. This update occurs in near-real-time. | | `delivered` | The status changes from `guaranteed` to `delivered` when funds have been sent to you in your daily batch disbursement. Transactions will update to delivered at a set time each day. | | `failed` | The status applies for online payments like credit cards. If the payer tries to pay with a card and thereâ€™s an issue to collect the funds, a failed status update will be triggered. This update will contain information about the card used and the reason why it failed. Any new attempt will trigger a new failed attempt or the status will channge to `processed` if the retry succeeds. | | `cancelled` | The status changes from `initiated` to `cancelled` when the payment has either been cancelled by either the payer or expired. Note that `guaranteed` and `delivered` payments cannot be cancelled by the payer. | The `delivered` status is the **only** terminal status - it is not possible for the status of a payment marked as `delivered` to change. ## Message Structure For each change to a paymentâ€™s status the Flywire payments platform will send a POST request to the specified â€‹callback URL containing the following JSON payload: ```json { "event_type": "initiated", "event_date": "2021-10-12 19:26:01 UTC", "data": { "payment_id": "MMM952072105", "amount_from": "106200", "currency_from": "EUR", "amount_to": "120000", "currency_to": "USD", "status": "initiated", "expiration_date": "2021-10-14T21:08:52Z", "external_reference": "1234", "country": "ES", "payment_method": { "type": "card", "brand": "mastercard", "card_classification": "credit", "card_expiration": "03/2030", "last_four_digits": "5454" }, "fields": { "booking_reference": "REF-1234" } } } ``` ```json { "event_type": "processed", "event_date": "2021-10-12 19:26:01 UTC", "data": { "payment_id": "MMM952072105", "amount_from": "106200", "currency_from": "EUR", "amount_to": "120000", "currency_to": "USD", "status": "processed", "expiration_date": "2021-10-14T21:08:52Z", "external_reference": "1234", "country": "ES", "payment_method": { "type": "card", "brand": "mastercard", "card_classification": "credit", "card_expiration": "03/2030", "last_four_digits": "5454" }, "fields": { "booking_reference": "REF-1234" } } } ``` ```json { "event_type": "guaranteed", "event_date": "2021-10-12 19:26:01 UTC", "data": { "payment_id": "MMM952072105", "amount_from": "106200", "currency_from": "EUR", "amount_to": "120000", "currency_to": "USD", "status": "guaranteed", "expiration_date": "2021-10-14T21:08:52Z", "external_reference": "1234", "country": "ES", "payment_method": { "type": "card", "brand": "mastercard", "card_classification": "credit", "card_expiration": "03/2030", "last_four_digits": "5454" }, "fields": { "booking_reference": "REF-1234" } } } ``` ```json { "event_type": "delivered", "event_date": "2021-10-12 19:26:01 UTC", "data": { "payment_id": "MMM952072105", "amount_from": "106200", "currency_from": "EUR", "amount_to": "120000", "currency_to": "USD", "status": "delivered", "expiration_date": "2021-10-14T21:08:52Z", "external_reference": "1234", "country": "ES", "payment_method": { "type": "card", "brand": "mastercard", "card_classification": "credit", "card_expiration": "03/2030", "last_four_digits": "5454" }, "fields": { "booking_reference": "REF-1234" } } } ``` ```json { "event_type": "failed", "event_date": "2021-10-12T21:09:17Z", "data": { "payment_id": "MMM468123850", "amount_from": "106200", "currency_from": "EUR", "amount_to": "120000", "currency_to": "USD", "status": "failed", "expiration_date": "2021-10-14T21:08:52Z", "external_reference": "1234", "country": "ES", "payment_method": { "type": "card", "brand": "mastercard", "card_classification": "credit", "card_expiration": "02/2022", "last_four_digits": "5454" }, "fields": { "booking_reference": "REF-1234" }, "reason": "Your transaction has not been successful, please try again. If the error persists select a different payment method or contact our customer support team.", "reason_code": "056" } } ``` ```json { "event_type": "cancelled", "event_date": "2021-10-12 21:12:29 UTC", "data": { "payment_id": "MMM952072105", "amount_from": "106200", "currency_from": "EUR", "amount_to": "120000", "currency_to": "USD", "status": "cancelled", "expiration_date": "2021-10-21T19:26:01Z", "external_reference": "1234", "country": "ES", "payment_method": { "type": "bank_transfer" }, "fields": { "booking_reference": "1234" }, "cancellation_reason": "expired" } } ``` ### Payload | Property | Description | | ------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | `event_type` | The status of the payment [`initiated`, `processed`, `guaranteed`, `delivered`, `cancelled`, `failed`] | | `event_date` | The time of the status change | | `data` | [Object](/en/webhooks/notifications-v2/#data-object) that contains additional info about the payment | ### Data Object | Property | Description | | --------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `payment_id` | Flywireâ€™s unique ID for the payment | | `amount_from` | Payment amount in payer's originating currency specified in subunits (ie. â‚¬15.49 would be 1549) | | `currency_from` | Payer's origintating currency | | `amount_to` | Payment amount in recipient's settlement currency in subunits (ie. \$10.99 would be 1099) | | `currency_to` | Recipient's originating currency | | `status` | The status of the payment [`initiated`, `processed`, `guaranteed`, `delivered`, `cancelled`, `failed`] | | `expiration_date` | The date in which the booking will expire | | `external_reference` | Your unique reference that was set during the original payment initialization (if using the [checkout](/en/checkout/implementation/#webhook-notifications), the value would be your `callbackId`) | | `country` | The country the payer is paying from | | `payment_method` | [Object](/en/webhooks/notifications-v2/#payment-method-object) containing details around the payment's method | | `fields` | Object containing any custom field data (check [Your Portal Configuration](/en/portal-configuration/) to see your custom fields) | | `cancellation_reason` | Cancelation reason [`expired`, `cancelled_by_user`, `rejected`, `duplicated`] | | `reason` | Human friendly description behind why the payment had failed | | `reason_code` | Error code that provides more details about the failure | ### Payment Method Object | Property | Description | | ------------------------------------------------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------------- | | `type` | Method of transaction [`bank_transfer`, `online`, `credit_card`] | | `brand`\* | Brand of the card [`visa`, `mastercard`, `amex`] | | `card_classification`\* | Classification of the card [`credit`, `debit`] | | `card_expiration`\* | Expiration date of the card (MM/YYYY) | | `last_four_digits`\* | Last four digits of the card | \* The fields marked by the asterisk are only returned for specific card payments. Please check with your account manager to see if you should expect to receive these fields in your payment method object. ### Retry Policy When Flywire tries to send a notification to a callback URL and we receive an error, we automatically re-attempt three times and log all failures: 1. After a delay of 180 seconds (3 minutes) 2. After a delay of 1800 seconds (30 minutes) 3. After a delay of 10800 seconds (3 hours) When using the callback feature please refer to our [payment scenarios](/en/webhooks/notifications-v2/#payment-flows) to ensure that you have all use cases covered. ## Authentication In order to verify the integrity and authenticity of messages sent to your web-hook these POST requests can include a X-Flywire-Digest header. The `X-Flywire-Digest` header is the base 64 encoded HMAC SHA256 hash of the message body and a shared secret. Please contact your account manager to arrange the transfer of your shared secret. ```js const crypto = require("crypto"); app.post("/flywire-notification", (req, res) => { const notification = req.body; const sharedSecret = "YOUR SHARED SECRET"; const requestDigest = req.header("X-Flywire-Digest"); const serverDigest = digest(notification, sharedSecret); if (requestDigest === serverDigest) { // Process notification } res.sendStatus(200); }); function digest(data, sharedSecret) { const hmac = crypto.createHmac("sha256", sharedSecret); hmac.update(JSON.stringify(data)); return hmac.digest("base64"); } ``` ```php $value) { if ($name == $header) { return $value; } } } ?> ``` ## Payment Flows We ask all clients using the callback features to verify the following payment progression and regression cases during testing to ensure their systems are capable of handling our callbacks appropriately. To understand these case scenarios there is an assumed knowledge of the general Flywire funds flow. For more context, please speak with your account manager. It is important to understand the context of each case and its potential impact on how you intend to use Flywire. Depending on your implementation some scenarios may not directly impact your processes. ### Standard Payment 1. `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `delivered` (using bank transfer as the payment method) 2. `initiated` > `guaranteed` > `delivered` (using card or an online payment method) 3. `initiated` > `cancelled` (using any payment method) The success of these three tests allow us to confirm that the core payment flows operate as expected in the overall user process. ### Re-initiated Cancelled Payment 1. `initiated` > `cancelled` > `initiated` > `processed` > `guaranteed` > `delivered` (using bank transfer as the payment method) This test ensures that your platform does not recognise `cancelled` as an absolute end-point. Payment Scenario: A bank transfer payment is cancelled automatically when Flywire does not receive the funds. Although this booking now has a status of `cancelled`, it is possible that the payer sent funds that did not arrive before the automatic cancellation, or funds were delayed because of their bank. If Flywire receives the funds after the automatic cancellation, providing that the FX rate position is similar, Flywire will still process the payment against the same payment ID, moving the status from `cancelled` to `initiated` and back through the standard path. ### Held Payment 1. `initiated` > `processed` > `guaranteed` > `initiated` (due to a hold release) > `delivered` 2. `initiated` > `processed` > `guaranteed` > `cancelled` In both cases above, the payment is placed on hold, this is an internal status which translates to an `initiated` status being communicated in the callback. The reasons why a payment could be placed on hold are: **Payment Scenario A:â€‹** A payment made via card or an online method has been `guaranteed`, however, prior to Flywire disbursing funds to the client, the payer contacts Flywire as theyâ€™ve made a mistake and would like a refund. Flywire would place this payment on hold and contact you to confirm whether we should deliver the funds despite the refund request or return the funds to the payer. We would not return these funds without your approval **Payment Scenario B:â€‹** A payment is made via any method and Flywire receive the funds. The transaction is flagged as suspicious and is placed on hold. The payment is manually checked to determine legitimacy. If the alert is deemed to be a false positive, Flywire will deliver the funds. If the payment is deemed to be suspicious and/or the alert cannot be deemed a false-positive, Flywire will notify the client and return the funds to the payer ### Guaranteed with Different Amount `initiated` (\$2000) > `processed` (\$2000) > `guaranteed` (amount changed) > `delivered` This can only occur when using bank transfer as the payment method as the payments are completed outside of the Flywire platform. **Payment Scenario**: A payer books an exchange rate with Flywire to send \$2000 via bank transfer. An `initiated` status and value of $2000 is sent via the callback notification. When the payer sends funds via online banking or at their physical bank, they send above or below the quoted amount of $2000. Flywire will accept this amount if it is within an accepted threshold. A `guaranteed` status with an updated value in the amount parameter is sent to the client via the notification. Flywire amount change tolerances are: - 200.00 USD or equivalent under the booked exchange amount - 1000.00 USD or equivalent over the booked exchange amount Outside of these tolerances, if a payment is excessively under or over the `initiated` value, we will contact you to ask if you would like to accept the payment or return it back to the payer. At this stage, the booking would be placed on hold and follow the [payments on hold flow](#held-payment). The `guaranteed` amount will always be the same as the `delivered` amount.
